page.title: 17DRAYCOTE WATERS
page.content: The Draycote scheme cost 3 million pounds! Work began in 1967. Draycote water lies in a basin bounded by the Mensborough hills to the south and the high ground near the village of Thurlaston and the M45 to the north. There is nearly a square mile of water, five miles of banks and the reservoir holds 5000 million gallons, with a maximum depth of 68ft. Water enters the reservoir from Eathorpe pumping station through two upturned bell mouths into a stilling basin and down a cascade to provide aeration and prevent scour. There is an overflow weir with breakwaters to prevent loss of water. It is extensively used for recreation and in particular for trout fishing and sailing.
